description.plain:
Cam'ron and Rap Genius founder VeggieCrumble (aka Ilan Zechory)

Cameron “Cam'ron” Giles is perhaps the quintessential Rap Genius artist.  Funny (like us), boastful (ditto), clever (yup), and rich (well..)

Killa Cam started out alongside Big L, Ma$e, his cousin Bloodshed (R.I.P.) and others in the short-lived group Children of the Corn.  He had several successful solo albums, but it’s his 2004 record Purple Haze that stands as the quintessence of all things Cam'ronian.

Since then, Cam has kept his computers ‘puting on a series of albums and mixtapes by himself, with Dipset, and with his standout new protege Vado.  We here at RG salute Mr. Giles, without whom this site might not exist.  May your diamonds keep on doing the Macarena.

description.plain:
“Hey Ma” was the second single off of Cam'ron’s 2002 breakthrough record Come Home With Me (after “Oh Boy”). This was also one of Juelz Santana’s earliest features, and remains Cam'ron’s biggest single to date.

It samples the 1977 hit “Easy” by The Commodores .

songs.full_title: Killa Cam by Cam'ron (Ft. Opera Steve)
songs.title: Killa Cam

description.plain:
Not only was Cam'ron’s 2004 sophomore Roc-A-Fella release Purple Haze “the album that launched a thousand rap blogs,” it’s also responsible for this very website!

“Killa Cam” was the first song on Genius (then RapGenius, of course). Co-founder Mahbod Moghadam once said:

[T]he purpose of Rap Genius was for us to meet Cam’ron… We wanted to have a Yale Master’s Tea, a snobby event they do at Yale, with Cam'ron to have a good time and introduce Killa to some college girls!

The song, of course, is an exemplary Cam joint, featuring vibrant wordplay, mucho bravado, and extensive pop culture references. The title (and hook) refer to Cam'ron’s longtime nickname, which originated from his time in ‘90s rap group Children of the Corn.

This page and its annotations have even been approved by Cam'ron’s mother:

https://twitter.com/virgie_G/status/147349360332648448

description.plain:
Kanye coming with the 70s Heron flow, classic as always

Cam'ron lets Kanye make his beats, but – in a utility-maximizing move – forbids him from rapping.

Kanye has stated that this is his favorite beat that he didn’t really do. Brian “All Day” Miller did the beat, and both shared co-production credit.

description.plain:
The lyrics to this song are of the sort that Cam gets made fun of for writing: nursery rhyme-sounding, lots of allusions to t.v. commercials and other immature memes. They used to make fun of James Joyce for doing this sort of thing, too

Carl Orff’s “Carmina Burana – O Fortuna” is sampled for the beat. As in Killa Cam, the hook features a woman singing Cam'ron’s name over and over again

description.plain:
The Diplomats aka “Dipset” is a movement that you’ve got to be in tune with. Sort of like a family, except all dudes.

A disagreement about the meaning of this song’s lyrics between Tom Lehman and Ilan Zechory made them want to create a website based on crowdsourcing to explicate lyrics. Rap Genius was born !

songs.full_title: Dipshits by Cam'ron (Ft. Dame Dash & Juelz Santana)
songs.title: Dipshits

description.plain:
“Dipshits” dropped on May 14, 2014 — the 12th anniversary of Come Home With Me’s release. The track was heralded as a Dipset reunion (after nearly a decade of relative inactivity). The track was announced as part of the Federal Reserve EP, a collaboration between Cam'ron and A-Trak. However, as of March 2015, nothing new from that project has materialized, and while Cam'ron is optimistic, A-Trak has implied that the future of the project may be in doubt.

The Ricky Saiz-directed music video features the Diplomats (including a cameo from Jim Jones) stunting around Harlem.

songs.full_title: Wet Wipes by Cam'ron
songs.title: Wet Wipes

description.plain:
“Wet Wipes” was released as a single from Cam'ron’s Killa Season and is about the ladies using wet wipes to make sure their private areas are so fresh and so clean. The Alchemist chops up the intro from rock group Earth & Fire’s 1972 track “Memories,” and he talked about the production in an interview with Complex:


That was a turning point for me cause that was the first beat I made on an MPC. Since then I’ve been messing with the MPC. That ushered in the style I was doing at the time because I chopped a lot on ‘Wet Wipes. On some nerdy producer shit, I was trying to move the samples like how you would move high hats like chop shit and pitch it up.

I had this whole style in my mind that I was trying to do and I did a whole batch of beats like that. ‘Wet Wipes’ was the first that came out. The next was Evidence’s ‘Let Yourself Go’ which is a similar style. Then I did it on Chemical Warfare’s ‘Keep The Heels On.’ Then I did it on Wayne’s album [Tha Carter III’s ‘You Ain’t Got Nuthin’] which was also like that.

songs.full_title: It's Killa by Cam'ron
songs.title: It’s Killa

description.plain:
Cam continues a 20 year old rap beef with Ma$e, a fellow Harlem rapper with whom he was in a group in. “Children of the Corn” consisted of Big L, Cam'ron, Ma$e, Herb McGruff, and Bloodshed.

On “It’s Killa,” Cam talks about his early years in Harlem since the statute of limitations is over and he can’t be indicted for revealing information about old crimes.

A quintessential Cam song – bragging about his shoes one minute, mourning his dead cousin the next, and somehow finding time for a Little Shop of Horrors reference which is an American  rock musical horror comedy film.



He also makes a little reference to the hit film Paid in full which he appears.

description.plain:
Ah, the lighthearted completion of Cam'ron’s “Losing Weight Trilogy” (this song mimics the hooks from Cam’s classics: “Losing Weight pt. 1” and “Losing Weight pt. 2”)

Whereas “Losing Weight” refers to the perils of life as a small-time drug dealer (getting your stash stolen, your money robbed, etc.) – “Moving Weight” is written from the big-dogg perspective, more common in rap music

songs.full_title: Dinner Time by Cam'ron
songs.title: Dinner Time

description.plain:
Cam'ron didn’t take long to respond to Ma$e’s diss track “The Oracle” as he unleashed “Dinner Time” only two days later.

The Harlem MC and Diplomats representative teased the The Heatmakerz-produced record on Instagram following the release of “The Oracle” and also made the claim that Ma$e was running a ponzi scheme when he transitioned out of rap to work as a pastor.

Cam touches on that in “Dinner Time,” as well as calling into question Ma$e’s true roots to Harlem.

Why you talking Harlem? You from Jacksonville Florida

Cam also responds to the rumor that he had sex with his own sister, as proclaimed by Ma$e.

I ain’t got a sister, only sister I fucked was yours

For what it’s worth, Mase’s sister previously denied that happened.

Cam also alleges Ma$e ​was involved in some type of sexual activity with a dildo at Puff Daddy’s house, who Ma$e has been aligned with since the Bad Boy  days in the late ‘90s.

So you gon' tell me when you was staying with Puff, and I came over there and used the bathroom there wasn’t a dildo on the sink?

description.plain:
Cam recounts his romance with a childhood sweetheart. He eventually must make a decision between hustling and keeping his girlfriend; guess which one he chooses!

The production team Pop & Versatile sample Smokey Robinson’s “Merry-Go-Ride”.

songs.full_title: More Reasons by Cam'ron (Ft. Jaheim)
songs.title: More Reasons

description.plain:
More Reasons is Cam'ron telling the story of how the desire for money, popularity with girls, and notoriety led him from sports, to drug sales, to entertainment.
It also recounts some of Cameron Giles real-life early interactions with Jim Jones and late former group member, Bloodshed

From Purple Haze (2004), this song features Jaheim on the chorus. More Reasons samples Reasons by Earth, Wind, and Fire for the track production and features and interpolation of the same song for the chorus

songs.full_title: Girls by Cam'ron (Ft. Mona Lisa)
songs.title: Girls

description.plain:
Girls, specifically your girl, just want to have fun by cheating on you with Cam'ron. The video features a hilarious portrayal of this with the pathetic, controlling “Smoke” character.

This was the second single off of Purple Haze and the sequel to “Stop Calling”.

On Charlemagne’s sampling of Cyndi Lauper’s “Girls Just Want to Have Fun”, Cam has stated, “I always loved the record … I was a wrestling fan, and Captain Lou Albano was in the video. At this point in my career, seeing what girls are doing, I thought it was time to bring it back out. They be wilding! I think it’s gonna be a good summer record.”

songs.full_title: 10,000 miles by Cam'ron
songs.title: 10,000 miles

description.plain:
“10,000 miles” describes a messed up relationship after Cam'ron himself is discovered cheating his girlfriend multiple times, resulting in a rant of sleeping with different girls again as a remedy and eventually having to confess and show guilt.

The track is the first single off the official soundtrack for the Clifton Bell-directed movie 10,000 miles, which will be released in the summer of 2017.

The track samples the well-known “A Thousand Miles” by Vanessa Carlton, and describes a love life full of problems.
